name: IJJ
comment info:
Let’s take the main message from these data as foreign born
Workers are, over time, playing a larger role in the U.S (and most other “Western” countries).

The question this raises is why politicians can’t be honest with their electorate:

- we need them (our “domestic” population is growing sufficiently for the roles needed).
- they are good for our economy - migrants are typically more geographically fluid in the labour market than
Those with deep seated family roots in specific areas.
- they pay their taxes and break laws at a lower rate than “domestic” citizens.

Until the Right (let’s  be honest, it’s mostly the Right) stop treating this group as some sort of evil scourge and instead as an asset to the Nation we can’t move this debate forward.

My own tiny example, I moved from the UK to New York in the 90’s - I thought all my Christmases had arrived at once.

If I was given the same choice today, given the toxicity of our national debate, I’d have come straight to Asia to build my career.

name: Enrique L
comment info:
At the start of the pandemic (x: 2020) both workforces intercept (y: 100%). Soon after (x~2020.2), the decline is much greater for workforce foreign-born (less than 92%) than it is for native-born (about 96%).
In the economic recovery period (x-axis from about 2021.5 to about 2022.75), which corresponds with the global effort to distribute covid vaccines and to minimize lockdowns, there’s a steep increase in the foreign-born workforce (from y axis: 95 to 106).  That means that it went from (30x0.95 to 30x1.06, which corresponds to 3.3millions increase. But, the native-born workforce didn’t increase or declined for this period.

In South Florida, healthcare saw a significant influx of foreign-born workers.   Many had ties to immigrants that had lived in South Florida for decades. But others came from places that had low-immigration history to South Florida. 
Depending on the kind of job (industry), many of these workers were either working illegally (through agencies) or legally (with temporary permits). 
Among other issues (higher rents and overcrowding places), there is a traffic problem in South Florida cities. And, places like Miami, FL didn’t seem interested in incentivizing public transportation or building more infrastructure to make options more appealing. So, traffic congestion and long commutes have become just the norm to get to work (or anywhere at any time).

Headline: In the U.S., millions of jobs happened for foreign-born workers after the pandemic. But, how?

name: Tim
comment info:
The "percentage" label is misleading because the denominators for the two lines are not the same: 30m for foreign-born, 130m for US-born. The different denominators amplify the changes in the (absolute) foreign worker data by over 4 times in the plot, relative to changes in US born, so comparing the two lines is useless.

The line for foreign-born people has a higher slope after the pandemic than before, but the dip after the pandemic is deeper (at least, plotted this way.) This shows more hiring after the pandemic, but the percentage of foriegn-born workers in the workforce at any particular time is nowhere on this graph.

replies.name: Z
replies.comment info:
@Moderator Sharon Fair questions. But if you read the other comments you will note how many misinterpret what the graph is saying. That is a problem for a newspaper (this isn’t a graph in a research paper read by experts). 

As for a different kind of graph? Simply show the change in the percentage of workers who are foreign-born and those who are native-born (e.g., from 2020 to 2024: 82%/18% to 80%/20%). Not as dramatic but easy to interpret. I would also like to see data that goes farther back to slunderstand this in historic context. What was the percentage in 1920, for example? 1880? (If quality data exists.)

Also, as a couple of posters have commented, it would be more enlightening to see this broken down by industry. Where is the growth happening most quickly? Are there places where the trend is the opposite? Is it happening in technology companies, with college-educated technologists being brought in? low-paid jobs in agriculture or service industries? What about health care and at what level of service? (Nurses, aids, doctors?) 

Some answers to these questions can be found here:https://nfap.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/Immigrants-And-Americas-Labor-Force-Growth.DAY-OF-RELEASE.October-2024.pdf. The source is a non-partisan, non-profit think tank. For example, foreign-born now make up more than a quarter of all doctorate holders (e.g., PhDs) compared to about 16% in 1994.

replies.comment info:
HI, @Patti G --

You are right on what the implication of this graph:  There is an “increasing need of skills that the US base work force doesn’t have or just can’t provide on order to meet industry demands.”  But, I do not understand why you “predict a possible downturn.”  Please explain.

A few comments on some of the math concepts you mention. 

When I think of inversely proportional I think of, for example, the more cookies I eat, the fewer there are in the cookie box.  Do you see this in the graph?  Please share your thoughts.

When there is exponential growth, a value increases by a rate over time.  For example, if your bank pays compound interest, your money in the bank increases exponentially, with each new amount of interest greater than the interest earned in the prior period.

A cycle repeats itself, like a the tides or trig functions.  Other than within any year when there is an increase in the work force for Christmas holiday season, where do you see a cycle?  Explain where you see a cycle.

replies.comment info:
Hi, @Tessa(AOSE). You ask a question that's critical to understanding the graph - "how the percentage goes above 100%".  The explanation below the graph points out that the "graph displays separately the percentage difference in their number in the U.S. work force when compared to their baseline number in the work force in February 2020".  So they are calling the number of foreign born workers in February 2020 "100%", and showing the numbers of workers at all the other times as a percentage of that February 2020 number.

Can you think of some other examples you've seen where someone explains what "one whole" or "one hundred percent" is in their story?

It's worth making sure you talk about this with your classmates, because it's really helpful when trying to understand stories that people are trying to tell with numbers.

name: Moderator Sharon
comment info:
Hi Math Buddies and Graph Analyzers -- 

Did you know that number and amount are used for different kinds of quantities?

Number is used when you can count something, like number of workers.

Amount is used when the quantity can't be counted, like amount of work.  (You do say:  "the number of hours to complete my work.")

Also, be careful "reading" this graph.  Read the headline to understand what is being measured.  Read the three paragraphs below the graph to get a better understanding of the values on the y-axis.

Once you understand what is being measured, start noticing and wondering.

comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's live moderation of “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  Today’s graph is about the growth in the number of native- and foreign-born workers in the U.S. as compared to the number at the start of the pandemic recession in February 2020.  

Note that the number of native- and foreign-born workers at the February 2020 baseline is 134 million and 30 million, respectively.  Both are 100 percent at the baseline.  The percentages are the percentage change from the baseline.

By Friday morning, we’ll reveal the free link to the online article that included this graph, shout outs for some of the catchiest headlines and more.  

You can get a link to your response to share with your teacher and classmates by clicking the response box below your response “Email me when my comment is published.”  

The next graph will be released by Friday, February 28.  The topic will be vaccinations.

name: Daniel Vasquez
comment info:
Observations - This graph shows the % of workers above or below the Feb. 2020 baseline by their origin. From 2015 to 2020, the % of native born workers was relatively constant, while the % of foreign born workers steadily increased each year. However, after Feb 2020, both the %’s of native and foreign born workers dropped. Foreign Born workers % dropped significantly more than native born. Native Born %’s recovered relatively quickly, but foreign born %’s began increasing exponentially in from 2022 and onwards. 

Questions - I wonder what caused the percentage of foreign workers to increase so dramatically to the point it surpassed the % of native born workers. Why did native born workers not suffer as much of a decline as foreign-born, and how did they recover so fast? What industries were affected by these workforce changes and how does this impact the economy? 

Relation to Community - NJ has a diverse population and is home to many foreign-born residents. These trends could mark a shift in the local labor markets. Perhaps the sharp rise in foreign-born workers may signal new policy changes or labor shortages in certain industries.

Headline - "Who’s Filling the Jobs? Tracking the Shifts in Native and Foreign Labor"

name: Lasky AP Language Block 5
comment info:
We notice that the percentages of foreign-born and native-born workers compared to the February 2020 baseline dropped  (especially for foreign-born workers) at the start of the pandemic recession.  By 2024, the number of native-born workers returned to 100% of the Feb. 2020 baseline, and the number of foreign born workers increased by 9% above the baseline. 

We notice that the number of foreign-born workers were increasing even before the pandemic but rose steeply after the start of the pandemic recession.

We wonder why the pandemic recession initially impacted foreign-born workers more?
We wonder how immigration impacted the data?
We wonder why there was so much growth in foreign-born workers from 2020-2024?

This graph relates to us because we lived through the pandemic recession and some of our parents' jobs were impacted by it. 

Our catchy title is "Foreign-Born Workers Rebound After the Pandemic Recession."

name: Art Chippendale
comment info:
I notice:
1. The graph indicates that the percent of both groups were about equal at the start of the Pandemic. 
2. The percentage of Native workers dropped. But regained 4 points back to 100% recently. 
3. Meanwhile, the percentage of Foreign workers dropped 9%  during the pandemic, then rose 18 points to 109% last year. 
4. I also noticed information that was missing, like: the meaning of “Percentage” as in a percentage of what?
5. Also missing from the graph are the total number of workers in each group. 

I wondered why: 
Without a definition of “Percentage,” this graph implies that Foreign Born workers have gained more than Native Born workers since the Pandemic, and
that both together equal 209% of the workforce. which is not only mathematically impossible, it defies common sense!

These questions made me suspicious! 

I concluded that the graph displays percentages of some mysteriously missing factor of those actually employed by each group, and that by hiding such information, the publisher hopes to mislead readers into believing that Foreign Born workers (ie. immigrants) are doing better than Native Born Americans!

My community has many workers from places all over the world, just trying to make a living and paying their taxes. I can already see them leaving by the dozen however, and I wonder how it will affect our economy.

name: Yvonne
comment info:
This is the kind of graph I would expect to see in a book called „How to Lie with Statistics.“ Three reasons why are
1. the small changes are exaggerated by using an x-axis that does not go down to zero so that a it makes a 10% increase then a slight dip in foreign born workers look like a much bigger change than it is
2. by using percentages of two wildly different numbers (130 to 30) it makes the two populations appear to be about the same size
3. finally, even though the actual number of foreign workers remains far below native born workers, this graph makes it look like the number of foreign born workers is outpacing the number of native born workers, and additionally, it makes it look like whatever policy was enacted recently has made this trend reverse when in reality it is likely just a blip that wouldn’t show up in an absolute graph with a zero axis.

replies.name: B
replies.comment info:
@Patrick 

The rise isn't that huge. Actually it just "erased" the covid decrease, as the level is now in the continuity of the trend of the pre-pandemic period.

However, the level has not completely recovered among natives. This might be explained by the structure of the economy by sectors, but I don't know enough about the US labour market to tell. It's also rather curious that bumps in on curve often correspond to the opposite bump in the other.

Put together, it might suggest a competition between natives and foreign workers, and foreign workers do better, likely because they are much cheaper.

Which, incidentally, tends to justify an anti-immigration policy. But such a policy would likely drive prices up, because of lower unemployment and better wages. I'm not an experth though...
